key_points: A company recently paid $850,000 in ransom after hackers encrypted their data and demanded $1.2 million.
Hackers also threatened to release 1 terabyte of the company's sensitive data if the ransom was not paid.
The attack is part of a growing wave of ransomware incidents targeting businesses, governments, and other entities globally.
More than half of the victims of ransomware attacks end up paying a ransom, with the average ransom paid last year estimated at about $312,000.
The Colonial Pipeline attack highlighted ransomware's potential threat to national security and the economy.
President Biden indicated that criminals behind major ransomware attacks are believed to be based in Russia and called for Moscow to take action.
DarkSide, the group behind the Colonial Pipeline attack, announced it was shutting down after losing control of its servers, though some suspect it might be an exit scam.
Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin have facilitated the growth of ransomware by enabling untraceable transactions.
The Ransomware Task Force reported nearly 2,400 U.S. health care facilities, schools, and governments were hit by ransomware last year, with victims paying an estimated $400 million in ransoms.
Companies specializing in ransomware attack negotiations have emerged, indicating the unique challenges and decisions victims face.
spokespersons: Austin Berglas (Former Head of Cyber Branch, FBI's New York Field Office, Now Global Head of Professional Services, BlueVoyant)
Michael Daniel (President and CEO, Cyber Threat Alliance)
